But the truth is, I never had affection,
Or any liking to this Niece of hers.
You fore-saw somewhat then?
I had my notes,
And my Prognostics.
You read Almanacs,
And study them to some purpose, I believe?
I do confess, I do believe, and pray too:
According to the Planets at sometimes.
And do observe the sign in making Love:
As in Phlebotomy.
And choose your Mistress
By the good days, and leave her by the bad?
I do, and I do not.
A little more
Would fetch all this Astronomy from Allestree.
I tell you Master. Compasse, as my friend,
And under seal, I cast mine eye long since,
Upon the other wench, my Lady's woman,
Another manner of piece for handsomeness,
Than is the Niece (but that is sub sigillo,
And as I give it you) in hope of your aid,
And counsel in the business.
You need counsel?
The only famous Counsel, of the kingdom,
And in all Courts? that is a Jeer in faith,
Worthy your name, and your profession too,
Sharpe Master. Practise.
No, upon my Law,
As I am a Bencher, and now double Reader,
I meant in mere simplicity of request.
If you meant so. The affairs are now perplexed,
And full of trouble, give them breath, and settling,
I will do my best. But in meantime do you
Prepare the Parson, (I am glad to know
This; for myself liked the young Maid before,
And loved her too.) Have you a Licence?
No;
But I can fetch one straight.
Do, do, and mind
The Parsons pint to engage him -- the business;
A knitting Cup there must be.
I shall do it.
It is an affront, from you Sir; you here brought me,
Unto my Ladies, and to woo a wife,
Which since is proved a cracked commodity;
She hath broke bulk too soon.
No fault of mine,
If she be cracked in pieces, or broke round;
It was my sisters fault, that owns the house,
Where she hath got her clap, makes all this noise.
I keep her portion safe, that is not scattered:
The moneys rattle not; nor are they thrown,
To make a Muse, yet among the gamesome Suitors.
Can you endure that stout, close Master. Bias,
And have been so bred in the Politics?
The injury is done you, and by him only;
He lent you impressed money, and upbraids it:
Furnished you for the wooing, and now waves you.
That makes me to expostulate the wrong
So with him, and resent it as I do.
But do it home then.
Sir, my Lord shall know it.
And all the Lords of the Court too.
What a Moath
You are Sir Interest!
Wherein I entreat you,
Sweet Master Bias?
To draw in young States-men,
And heirs of policy into the noose
Of an infamous matrimony.
Yes,
Infamous, quasi in communem famam:
And Matrimony, quas, matter of Money.
Learnedly urged, my cunning Master. Bias.
With his lewd, known, and prostituted Niece.
My known, and prostitute: how you mistake,
And run upon a false ground, Master. Bias!
(Your Lords will do me right.) Now, she is prostitute,
And that I know it (please you understand me.)
I mean to keep the portion in my hands:
And pay no monies.
Mark you that Don Bias?
And you shall still remain in bonds to him,
For wooing furniture, and impressed charges.
Good Master. Compasse, for the sums he has had
Of me, I do acquit him: They are his own.
Here, before you, I do release him.
Good!
O Sir.
'Slid take it: I do witness it:
He cannot hurl away his money better.
He shall get so much Sir, by my acquaintance,
To be my friend: And now report to his Lords
As I deserve no otherwise.
But well:
And I will witness it, and to the value;
Four hundred is the price, if I mistake not,
Of your true friend in Court. Take hands, you have bought him,
And bought him cheap.
I am his worships servant.
And you his slave, Sir Moath. Sealed, and delivered.
Have you not studied the Court Complement?
Here are a pair of Humours, reconciled now,
That money held at distance: or their thoughts,
Baser than money.
Out thou caitiff witch!
Bawd, Beggar, Gypsy: Anything indeed,
But honest woman.
What you please, Dame Polish,
My Lady's Stroker.
What is here to do?
The Gossip is out!
Thou art a Traitor to me,
An Eve, the Apple, and the Serpent too:
A Viper, that hast eat a passage through me,
Through mine own bowels, by thy retchlessness.
What frantic fit is this? I will step aside
And hearken to it.
Did I trust thee, wretch,
With such a secret, of that consequence,
Did so concern me, and my child, our livelihood,
And reputation? And hast thou undone us?
By thy connivance, nodding in a corner,
And suffering her begot with child so basely?
Sleepy unlucky Hag! Thou bird of night,
And all mischance to me.
Good Lady Empress!
Had I the keeping of your Daughter's clicket
In charge? was that committed to my trust?
her Daughter.
Softly Devil, not so loud,
You would have the house hear, and be witness, would you?
Let all the world be witness. Afore I will
Endure the Tyranny of such a tongue --
And such a pride -- .
What will you do?
Tell truth,
And shame the She-man-Devil in puffed sleeves;
Run any hazard, by revealing all
Unto my Lady: how you changed the cradles,
And changed the children in them.
Not so high!
Calling your Daughter Pleasance, there Placentia,
And my true Mistress by the name of Pleasance.
A horrid secret, this! worth the discovery;
And must you be thus loud?
I will be louder:
And cry it through the house, through every room,
And every office of the Laundry-maids:
Till it be borne hot to my Lady's ears.
Ere I will live in such a slavery,
I will do away myself.
Didst thou not swear
To keep it secret? and upon what book?
(I do remember now) The Practice of Piety.
It was a practice of impiety,
Out of your wicked forge, I know it now,
My conscience tells me. First, against the Infants,
To rob them of their names, and their true parents;
To abuse the neighbour-hood, keep them in error;
But most my Lady: She has the main wrong:
And I will let her know it, instantly.
Repentance, (if it be true) never comes too late.
What have I done? Conjured a spirit up
I shall not lay again? drawn on a danger,
And ruin on myself thus, by provoking
A peevish fool, whom nothing will pray of,
Or satisfy I fear? her patience stirred,
Is turned to fury. I have run my Bark,
On a sweet Rock, by mine own arts, and trust:
And must get off again, or dash in pieces.
This was a business, worth the listening after.
O Master. Compasse, did you see my Mother?
Mistress Placentia, my Lady's Niece;
Is newly brought to bed of the bravest boy!
Will you go see it?
First, I will know the father,
Ere I approach these hazards.
Mistress Midwife
Has promised to find out a father for it,
If there be need.
She may the safelier do it,
By virtue of her place. But pretty Pleasance,
I have a news for you, I think will please you.
What is it Master. Compasse?
Stay, you must
Deserve it ere you know it. Where is my Lady?
Retired unto her Chamber, and shut up.
She hears of none of this yet? well, do you
Command the Coach; and fit yourself to travel?
A little way with me.
Whither, for Gods sake.
Where I will entreat you not to your loss, believe it.
If you dare trust yourself.
With you the world over.
The news will well requite the pains, I assure you.
And in this tumult you will not be missed.
Command the Coach, it is an instant business,
Would not be done without you. Parson Palate
Most opportunely met, step to my Chamber:
I will come to you presently. There is a friend,
Or two, will entertain you, Master. Practise.
Have you the Licence?
Here it is.
Let us see it:
Your name is not in it.
I will fill that presently;
It has the Seal, which is the main: And registered,
The Clarke knows me, and trusts me.
Have you the Parson?
They say he is here, he appointed to come hither.
I would not have him seen here for a world,
To breed suspicion. Do you intercept him,
And prevent that. But take your Licence with you,
And fill the blank: or leave it here with me,
I will do it for you, stay you with us at his Church,
Behind the old Exchange, we will come in the Coach,
And meet you there within this Quarter at least.
I am much bound unto you, Master. Compasse,
You have all the Law, and parts of Squire Practise
For ever at your use. I will tell you news too:
Sir, your Reversion is fallen: Thin-wits dead,
Survey of the Projects general.
When died he?
Even this morning, I received it
From a right hand.
Conceal it Master. Practise,
And mind the main affair, you are in hand with.
The Coach is ready Sir.
It is well fair Pleasance,
Though now we shall not use it, bid the Coach-man
Drive to the Parish Church, and stay about there,
Till Master. Practise come to him, and employ him:
I have a Licence now, which must have entry
Before my Lawyers. Noble Parson Palate,
Thou shalt be a mark advanced: here is a piece,
And do a feat for me.
What, Master. Compasse?
But run the words of Matrimony, over
My head, and Mistress. Pleasances in my Chamber:
There is Captain Ironside to be a witness:
And here is a Licence to secure thee. Parson!
What do you stick at?
It is afternoon Sir,
Directly against the Canon of the Church;
You know it Master. Compasse: and beside,
I am engaged unto our worshipful friend,
The learned Master. Practise in that business.
Come on, engage yourself:
Who shall be able
To say you married us, but in the morning,
The most canonical minute of the day,
If you affirm it? That is a spiced excuse,
And shows you have set the Common Law, before
Any profession else, of love, or friendship.
Come Mistress. Pleasance, we cannot prevail
With the rigid Parson here; but Sir, I will keep you
Locked in my lodging, till it be done elsewhere,
And under fear of Ironside.
Do you hear, Sir?
No, no, it matters not.
Can you think Sir
I would deny you anything? not to loss
Of both my Livings: I will do it for you,
Have you a wedding Ring?
Aye and a Poesy:
Annulus hic nobis, quod scit uterq; dabit.
Good!
This Ring will give you what you both desire.
I will make the whole house chant it, and the Parish.
Why, well said Parson. Now to you my news,
That comprehend my reasons, Mistress. Pleasance.
Go, get a Nurse, procure her at what rate
You can: and out of the house with it, son Needle.
It is a bad Commodity.
Good Mother,
I know it, but the best, would now be made of it.
And shall: you should not fret so, Mistress. Polish,
Nor you Dame Keep; my Daughter shall do well,
When she has taken my Caudle, I have known
Twenty such breaches pieced up, and made whole,
Without a bum of noise. You two fall out?
And tear up one another?
Blessed woman:
Blessed be the Peace-maker.
The Pease-dresser!
I will hear no peace from her. I have been wronged,
So has my Lady, my good Lady's worship,
And I will right her, hoping she will right me.
Good gentle Keep, I pray thee Mistress Nurse,
Pardon my passion, I was mystification,
Be thou yet better, by this grave sage woman,
Who is the Mother of Matrons, and great persons,
And knows the world.
I do confess, she knows
Something -- and I know something -- .
Put your somethings
Together then.
Aye, here is a chance fallen out
You cannot help; less can this Gentlewoman;
I can and will, for both. First, I have sent
By-chop away; the cause gone, the fame ceaseth.
Then by my Caudle, and my Cullis, I set
My Daughter on her feet, about the house here:
She is young, and must stir somewhat for necessity,
her youth will bear it out. She shall pretend,
To have had a fit of the Mother: there is all.
If you have but a Secretary Laundress,
To blanch the Linen -- Take the former counsels
Into you; keep them safe in your own breasts;
And make your Market of them at the highest.
Will you go peach, and cry yourself a fool
At Granam's Cross? be laughed at, and despised?
Betray a purpose, which the Deputy
Of a double Ward, or scarce his Alderman,
With twelve of the wisest Questmen could find out,
Employed by the Authority of the City?
Come, come, be friends; and keep these women-matters,
Smock secrets to ourselves,
in our own verge.
We shall mar all, if once we ope the mysteries
Of the Tiring-house, and tell what is done within:
No Theatres are more cheated with appearances,
Or these shop-lights, than the Ages, and folk in them,
That seem most curious.
Breath of an Oracle!
You shall be my dear Mother; wisest woman
That ever tipped her tongue, with point of reasons,
To turn her hearers! Mistress Keep, relent,
I did abuse thee; I confess to penance:
And on my knees ask thee forgiveness.
Rise,
She doth begin to melt, I see it -- .
Nothing
Grieved me so much, as when you called me Bawd:
Witch did not trouble me, nor Gypsy; no
Nor Beggar. But a Bawd, was such a name!
No more rehearsals; Repetitions
Make things the worse: The more we stir (you know
The Proverb, and it signifies a) stink.
What is done, and dead, let it be buried.
New hours will fit fresh handles, to new thoughts.

stage.l: Interest, with his Foot-boy. To them Compasse. Ironside.
Silkeworme. Palate. Pleasance. To them the

sp.l: Run to the church, Sirrah. Get all the Drunkards
To ring the Bells, and jangle them for joy
My Niece hath brought an Heir unto the house,
A lusty boy. Where is my sister Loadstone?
Asleep at the afternoons! It is not wholesome;
Against all rules of Physic, Lady sister.
The little Doctor will not like it. Our Niece
Is new delivered of a chopping Child,
Can call the Father by the name already,
If it but ope the mouth round. Master. Compasse,
He is the man, they say, fame gives it out,
Hath done that Act of honour to our house,
And friendship to pomp out a Son, and Heir,
That shall inherit nothing, surely nothing
From me at least. I come to invite your Ladyship
To be a witness; I will be your Partner,
And give it a horn-spoon, and a treen dish;
Bastard, and Beggars badges, and a blanket
For Dame the Doxy to march round the Circuit,
With bag, and baggage.
Thou malicious Knight,
Envious Sir Moath, that eats on that which feeds thee,
And frets her goodness, that sustains thy being;
What company of Mankind would own thy brother-hood,
But as thou hast a title of her blood,
Whom thy ill nature hath chose out to insult on,
And vex thus, for an Accident in her house,
As if it were her crime! Good innocent Lady,
Thou showest thyself a true corroding Vermin,
Such as thou art.
Why, gentle Master. Compasse?
Because I wish you joy of your young son,
And Heir to the house, you have sent us?
I have sent you?
I know not what I shall do. Come in friends:
Madam, I pray, you be pleased to trust yourself
Unto our company.
I did that too late;
Which brought on this calamity upon me,
With all the infamy I hear; your Soldier,
That swaggering Guest.
Who is returned here to you,
Your vowed friend, and servant; comes to sup with you,
So we do all; and will prove he hath deserved,
That special respect, and favour from you,
As not your fortunes, with yourself to boot,
Cast on a Feather-bed, and spread on the sheets
Under a brace of your best Persian Carpets,
Where scarce a price to thank his happy merit.
What impudence is this? can you endure
To hear it Sister?
Yes, and you shall hear it,
Who will endure it worse. What deserves he
In your opinion, Madam, or weighed Judgment,
That, things thus hanging (as they do in doubt)
Suspended, and suspected, all involved,
And wrapped in error, can resolve the knot?
Redintigrate the fame, first of your house?
Restore your Ladyships quiet? render then
Your Niece a Virgin, and unvitiated?
And make all plain, and perfect as it was)
A Practise to betray you, and your name?
He speaks impossibilities.
Here he stands,
Whose fortune hath done this, and you must thank him:
To what you call his swaggering, we owe all this.
And that it may have credit with you Madam,
Here is your Niece, whom I have married, witness
These Gentlemen, the Knight, Captain, and Parson,
And this grave Politic Tell-troth of the Court.
What is she that I call Niece then?
Polishes Daughter
her Mother Goodwy' Polish hath confessed it
To Graham Keep, the Nurse, how they did change
The children in their Cradles.
To what purpose?
To get the portion, or some part of it,
Which you must now disburse entire to me, Sir,
If I but gain her Ladyships consent.
I bid God give you joy, if this be true.
As true it is, Lady, lady, in the song.
The portion is mine, with interest Sir Moath;
I will not bate you a single Harrington,
Of interest upon interest. In mean time,
I do commit you to the Guard of Ironside.
My brother here, Captain Rudhudibras:
From whom I will expect you, or your Ransom.
Sir you must prove it, and the possibility,
Ere I believe it.
For the possibility,
I leave to trial. Trust shall speak itself.
O Master. Practise, did you meet the Coach?
Yes Sir, but empty.
Why, I sent it for you,
The business is despatched here, ere you come;
Come in, I will tell you know: you are a man
Will look for satisfaction, and must have it.
So do we all, and long to hear the right.
Troth, I am one of those that labour with the same longing,
for it is almost puckered, and pulled into that knot, by your Poet, which
I cannot easily, with all the strength of my imagination, untie.
Like enough, nor is it in your office to be troubled or perplexed
with it, but to sit still, and expect. The more your
imagination busies itself,
the more it is entangled, especially if (as I told, in the beginning)
you happen on the wrong end.
He hath said sufficient, Brother Damplay; our parts that are the
Spectators, or should hear a Comedy, are to await the process, and events
of things, as the Poet presents them, not as we would corruptly fashion
them. We come here to behold Plays, and censure them, as they are
made, and fitted for us; not to beslave
our own thoughts, with censorious
spittle tempering the Poet's clay, as we were to mold every Scene
anew: That were a mere Plastic, or Potters ambition, most unbecoming
the name of Gentleman. No, let us mark, and not lose the
business on foot, by talking. Follow the right thread, or find it.
Why, here his Play might have ended, if he would have let it;
and have spared us the vexation of a fifth Act yet to come,
here knows the issue of already, or may in part conjecture.
That conjecture is a kind of Figure-flinging, or throwing the
Dice, for a meaning was never in the Poet's purpose perhaps. Stay, and see
his last Act, his Catastrophe, how he will perplex that, or spring some
fresh cheat, to entertain the Spectators, with a convenient delight, till
some unexpected, and new encounter break out to rectify all, and make
good the Conclusion.
Which, ending here, would have shown dull, flat, and unpointed;
without any shape, or sharpness, Brother Damplay.
Well, let us expect then: And wit be with us, on the Poet's part.
Troth Master. Item, here is a house divided,
And quartered into parts, by your Doctor's engine.
He has cast out such aspersions on my Lady's
Niece here, of having had a Child; as hardly
Will be wiped off, I doubt.
Why, is it not true?
True! did you think it?
Was she not in labour?
The Mid-wife sent for?
There is your error now!
You have drunk of the same water.
I believed it,
And gave it out too.
More you wronged the party;
She had no such thing about her, innocent creature!
What had she then?
only a fit of the Mother!
They burnt old shoes, Goose-feathers, Assafoetida,
A few horn shavings, with a bone, or two,
And she is well again, about the house; --
Is it possible?
See it, and then report it.
Our Doctor's Urinal-Judgement is half-cracked then.
Cracked in the case, most hugely, with my Lady,
And sad Sir Moath, her brother; who is now
Under a cloud a little.
Of what? Disgrace?
He is committed to Rud-hudibras,
The Captain Ironside, upon displeasure,
From Master. Compasse, but it will blow off.
The Doctor shall reverse his, instantly,
And set all right again: if you will assist
But in a toy; Squire Needle, comes in my noddle now.
Good, Needle and Noddle! what may it be? I long for it .
Why, but to go to bed: fain a distemper
Of walking in your sleep, or talking in it
A little idly, but so much, as on it,
The Doctor may have ground, to raise a cure
For his reputation.
Anything, to serve
The worship of the man I love and honour.
O! give you joy Mademoiselle Compasse!
You are his Whirlpool now: all to be married,
Against your Mothers leave, and without counsel!
He has fished fair, and caught a Frog, I fear it.
What fortune have you to bring him in dower?
You can tell stories now: you know a world
Of secrets to discover.
I know nothing
But what is told me; nor can I discover
No, you shall not, I will take order.
Go, get you in there: It is Ember-week!
I will keep you fasting from his flesh a while.
See, who is here? she has been with my Lady: who kissed her, all
To kissed her, twice or thrice.
And called her Niece again, and viewed her Linen.
You have done a Miracle, Mother Chair.
Not I,
My Caudle has done it. Thank my Caudle heartily.
It shall be thanked, and you too, wisest Mother;
You shall have a new, brave, four-pound Beaver hat,
Set with enamelled studs, as mine is here:
And a right pair of Crystal Spectacles;
Crystal of the Rock, thou mighty Mother of Dames,
Hung in an Ivory Case, at a gold Belt,
And silver Bells to jingle, as you pace
Before your fifty Daughters in procession
To Church, or from the Church.
Thanks Mistress. Polish.
She does deserve as many pensions,
As there be pieces in a -- Maiden-head;
Were I a Prince to give them.
Come sweet Charge,
You shall present yourself about the house,
be confident, and bear up;
You shall be seen.
What? I can make you amends, my learned Counsel,
And satisfy a greater Injury
To chafed Master. Practise. Who would think
That you could be thus testy?
A grave head!
Given over to the study of our Laws.
And the prime honours of the Common-wealth.
And you to mind a wife.
What should you do
With such a toy as a wife, that might distract you,
Or hinder you in your Course?
He shall not think of it.
I will make over to you my Possession,
Of that same place is fallen (you know) to satisfy
Surveyor of the Projects general.
And that is an office, you know how to stir in.
And make your profits of.
Which are (indeed)
The ends of a gowned man: Show your activity,
And how you are built for business.
I accept it
As a Possession, be it but a Reversion.
You first told me it was a Possession.
Aye,
I told you that I heard so.
All is one,
He will make Reversion a Possession quickly.
But I must have a general Release from you.
do one, I will do the other.
It is a match
Before my brother Ironside.
It is done.
We two are reconciled then.
To a Lawyer,
That can make use of a place, any half title,
Is better than a wife.
And will save charges
Of Coaches, Vellute Gowns, and cutwork Smocks.
He is to occupy an office wholly.
True, I must talk with you nearer, Master. Practise,
About recovery of my wives portion,
What way I were best to take.
The plainest way.
What is that, for plainness?
Sue him at Common-Law!
Arrest him on an Action of Choke-bail,
Five hundred thousand pound; it will affright him,
And all his sureties. You can prove your marriage?
Yes.
We will talk of it within, and hear my Lady.
I am sure, the Rogue of the house went all that way;
She was with Child, and Master. Compasse got it.
Why, that you see, is manifestly false,
He has married the other; our true Niece he says:
He would not woo them both: he is not such
A Stallion, to leap all. Again, no Child
Appears, that I can find with all my search,
And strictest way of Inquiry, I have made
Through all my family. A fit of the Mother,
The women say she had, which the Mid-wife cured,
With burning bones and feathers: Here is the Doctor.
O noble Doctor, did not you, and your Item,
Tell me our Niece was in labour?
If I did,
What follows?
And that Mother Mid-night
Was sent for?
So she was, and is in the house still.
But here has a noise been since, she was delivered
Of a brave boy, and Master Compasse's getting.
I know no rattle of Gossips, nor their noises.
I hope you take not me for a Pimp errant,
To deal in smock Affairs? Where is the Patient?
The infirm man, I was sent for, Squire Needle
Is Needle sick?
My Apothecary tells me
He is in danger; how is it Tim? where is he?
I cannot hold him down. He is up, and walks,
And talks in his perfect sleep, with his eyes shut,
As sensibly, as he were broad awake.
See, here he comes. He is fast asleep, observe him.
He will tell us wonders: What do these women here?

stage.l: Rut. Needle. Interest. Item. Lady. Polish. Chaire.

sp.l: Hunting a man half naked? you are fine beagles!
You would have his doucets.
I have linen breeks on.
He hears, but he sees nothing.
Yes, I see
Who hides the treasure yonder.
Ha? what treasure?
If you ask questions, he wakes presently:
And then you will hear no more, till his next fit.
And whom she hides it for.
Do you mark Sir? list.
A fine she spirit it is, an Indian Mag-pie.
She was an Alderman's Widow, and fell in love
With our Sir Moath, my Lady's brother.
(Hear you?)
And she has hid an Alderman's estate;
Dropped through her bill in little holes, in the Garden,
And scrapes earth over them; where none can spy
But I, who see all by the Glowworm's light,
That creeps before.
I knew the Gentlewoman;
Alderman Parrots Widow, a fine Speaker,
As any was in the Clothing, or the Bevy;
She did become her scarlet, and black Velvet,
her green, and purple --
Save thy colours, Rainbow,
Or she will run thee over, and all thy lights.
She dwelt in Doo-little Lane, atop of the hill there;
In the round Cage, was after Sir Chime Squirrell's.
She would eat naught but Almonds, I assure you.
Would thou hadst a dose of pills, a double dose,
Of the best purge, to make thee turn tale, tother way.
You are a foul mouthed, purging, absurd Doctor;
I tell you true, and I did long to tell it you.
You have spread a scandal in my Lady's house here,
On her sweet Niece, you never can take off
With all your purges, or your plaster of Oaths;
Though you distill your Dam-me, drop by drop,
In your defence. That she hath had a Child,
Here she doth spit upon thee, and defy thee;
Or I do it for her.
Madam, pray you bind her
To her behaviour. Tie your Gossip up,
Or send her unto Bet'lem.
Go thou thither,
That better hast deserved it, shame of Doctors:
Where could she be delivered? by what charm?
Restored to her strength so soon? who is the Father?
Or where the Infant? Ask your Oracle,
That walks, and talks in his sleep.
Where is he? gone?
You have lost a fortune listening to her, to her Tabor.
Good Madam lock her up.
You must give losers
Their leave to speak, good Doctor.
Follow his footing
Before he get to his bed: This rest is lost else.
Where is my wife? what have you done with my wife,
Gossip of the Counsels?
I, sweet Master. Compasse?
I honour you, and your wife.
Well, do so still.
I will not call you Mother though, but Polish.
Good Gossip Polish, where have you hid my wife?
I hide your wife?
Or she is run away.
That would make all suspected, Sir, afresh.
Come we will find her, if she be in the house.
Why should I hide your wife, good Master. Compasse?
I know no cause, but that you are goody Polish,
That is good at malice; good at mischief; all
That can perplex, or trouble a business, thoroughly.
You may say what you will: you are Master. Compasse,
And carry a large sweep, Sir, in your Circle.
I will sweep all corners, Gossip, to spring this.
If it be above ground, I will have her cried,
By the Common-crier, through all the Ward,
But I will find her.
It will be an Act
Worthy your justice, Madam.
And become
The integrity, and worship of her name.
It is such a Fly, this Gossip, with her buzz,
She blows on everything, in every place!
A busy woman, is a fearful grievance!
Will he not sleep again?
Yes instantly,
As soon as he is warm. It is the nature
Of the disease, and all these cold dry fumes,
That are melancholic, to work at first,
Slow, and insensibly in their ascent,
Till being got up, and then distilling down
Upon the brain; they have a pricking quality
That breeds this restless rest, which we, the sons
Of Physic, call a walking in the sleep,
And telling mysteries that must be heard
Softly, with art, as we were sowing pillows
Under the Patients elbows, else they would fly
Into a Frenzy, run into the Woods,
Where there are Noises, huntings, shoutings, hallooings,
Amidst the brakes, and furzes, over bridges
Fall into waters: Scratch their flesh: Sometimes
Drop down a precipice, and there be lost.
How now! what does he?
He is up again,
And begins to talk.
Of the former matter, Item?
The treasure, and the Lady: That is his argument.
O me, happy man! he cannot off it.
I shall know all then.
With what appetite
Our own desires delude us! Hear you Tim?
Let no man interrupt us.
Sir Diaphanous,
And Master Bias, his Court-friend's, desire
To kiss his Niece's hands, and gratulate
The firm recovery of her good fame,
And honour --
Good, say to them, Master. Item,
My Niece is on my Lady's side: they will find her there.
I pray to be but spared, for half an hour:
I will see them presently.
Do, put them off, Tim.
And tell them the importance of the business.
Here, he is come! sooth; and have all out of him.
How do you Lady-bird? so hard at work, still?
What is that you say? Do you bid me walk, sweet Bird?
And tell our Knight? I will. How? walk knave, walk.
I think you are angry with me Pol. Fine Pol!
Pol is a fine bird! O fine Lady Pol!
Almond for Parrot; Parrot is a brave bird:
Three hundred thousand pieces have you stuck,
Edge-long into the ground, within the Garden?
O bounteous Bird!
And me, most happy creature.
Smother your joy.
How? and dropped twice so many --
Ha! where?
In the old Well?
I cannot, I am a man of flesh, and blood:
Who can contain himself, to hear the Ghost
Of a dead Lady, do such works as these?
And a City Lady too, of the straight waist?
He is gone.
I will go try the truth of it.
Follow him, Tim: See what he does; if he bring you
A essay of it now.
I will say he is a rare fellow:
And has a rare disease.
And I will work
As rare a cure upon him.
How, good Doctor?
When he hath uttered all, that you would know of him;
I will cleanse him with a pill (as small as a pease)
And stop his mouth: for there his issue lies,
Between the Muscles of the tongue.
He is come.
What did he, Item?
The first step he stepped
Into the Garden, he pulled these five pieces
Up, in a fingers breadth one of another.
The dirt sticks on them still.
I know enough,
Doctor, proceed with your Cure, I will make thee famous,
Famous among the sons of the Physicians,
Machaon, Podalirius, Esculapius.
Thou shalt have a golden beard, as well as he had;
And thy Tim Item here, have one of silver:
A livery beard. And all thy Apothecaries
Belong to thee. Where is Squire Needle? gone?
He is pricked away, now he has done the work.
Prepare his pill, and give it him afore Supper.
I will send for a dozen of labourers tomorrow,
To turn the surface of the Garden up.
In mold? bruise every clod?
And have all sifted;
For I will not lose a piece of the Birds bounty,
And take an Inventory of all.
And then,
I would go down into the Well --
No trusting other hands: Six hundred thousand,
To the first three; nine hundred thousand pound --
It will purchase the whole Bench of the Aldermanity,
Stripped to their shirts.
There never did accrue,
So great a gift to man, and from a Lady,
I never saw but one; now I remember,
We met at Merchants-Taylors-hall, at dinner,
In Thred-needle street,
Which was a sign Squire Needle
Should have the threading of this thread.
It is true;
I shall love Parrots better, while I know him.
I would have her statue cut, now in white marble.
And have it painted in most orient colours.
That is right! all City statues must be painted:
Else, they be worth naught in their subtle Judgments.
My truest friend in Court, dear Master. Bias;
You hear of the recovery of our Niece
In fame, and credit?
Yes, I have been with her,
And gratulated to her; but I am sorry
To find the Author of the foul aspersion
Here in your company, this insolent Doctor.
You do mistake him: He is clear got off of it.
A Gossip's Jealousy first gave the hint.
He drives another way, now, as I would have him.
He is a rare man, the Doctor, in his way.
He has done the noblest cure here, in the house,
On a poor Squire, my sisters Taylor, Needle
That talked in his sleep; would walk to Saint Iohn's wood;
And Waltham Forest, scape by all the ponds,
And pits in the way; run over two-inch bridges;
With his eyes fast, and in the dead of night!
I will have you better acquainted with him. Doctor,
Here is my dear, dear, dearest friend in Court,
Wise, powerful Master. Bias; pray you salute
Each other, not as strangers, but true friends.
This is the Gentleman you brought today,
A Suitor to your Niece?
Yes.
You were
Agreed, I heard; the writing drawn between you?
And sealed.
What broke you off?
This rumour of her?
Was it not Master. Bias?
Which I find
Now false, and therefore come to make amends
In the first place. I stand to the old conditions.
Faith give them him, Sir Moath, whatever they were.
You have a brave occasion now, to cross
The slanting Master. Compasse, who pretends
Right to the portion, by the other Entail.
And claims it. You do hear he is married?
We hear his wife is run away from him,
Within: She is not to be found in the house,
With all the Hue, and Cry is made for her,
Through every room; the Larders have been searched,
The Bake-houses, and Bolting-tub, the Ovens,
Wash-house, and Brew-house, nay the very Furnace,
And yet she is not heard of.
Be she never heard of,
The safety of Great Britain lies not on it.
You are content with the ten thousand pound,
Defalking the four hundred garnish money?
That is the condition here, afore the Doctor,
And your demand, friend Bias.
It is Sir Moath.
Here comes the Parson then, shall make all sure.
Go you with my friend Bias, Parson Palate,
Unto my Niece; assure them we are agreed.
And Mistress. Compasse too, is found within.
Where was she hid?
In an old Bottle-house,
Where they scraped trenchers; there her mother had thrust her.
You shall have time, Sir, to triumph on him,
When this fine feat is done, and his Rud-Ironside.
Was ever any Gentlewoman used
So barbarously by a malicious Gossip,
Pretending to be Mother to her too?
Pretending! Sir, I am her Mother, and challenge
A right, and power for what I have done.
Out, Hag.
Thou that hast put all nature off, and woman:
For sordid gain, betrayed the trust committed
Unto thee by the dead, as from the living:
Changed the poor innocent Infants in their Cradles:
Defrauded them of their parents, changed their names,
Calling Placentia, Pleasance; Pleasance, Placentia.
How knows he this?
Abused the neighbour-hood;
But most this Lady. Didst enforce an oath,
To this poor woman, on a pious book,
To keep close thy impiety.
Have you told this?
I told it? no, he knows it, and much more,
As he is a cunning man.
A cunning fool,
If that be all.
But now to your true daughter,
That had the Child, and is the proper Pleasance,
We must have an account of that too, Gossip;
This is like all the rest of Master. Compasse.
Help, help for Charity; Sir Moath Interest
is fallen into the Well.
Where? where?
In the Garden.
A rope to save his life.
How came he there?
He thought to take possession of a fortune,
There newly dropped him, and and the old Chain broke,
And down fell he in the Bucket.
Is it deep?
We cannot tell. A rope: help with a rope.

stage.l: Enter Silkeworme. Ironside. Item. Needle and Interest. Rut.

sp.l: He is got out again. the Knight is saved.
A little soused in the water: Needle saved him.
The water saved him, it was a fair escape.
Have you no hurt?
A little wet.
That is nothing.
I wished you stay Sir till tomorrow: and told you,
It was no lucky hour: since six o'Clock
All stars were retrograde.
In the name
Of fate, or folly how came you in the Bucket?
That is a Quaere of another time, sister,
The Doctor will resolve you -- who hath done
The admirablest cure upon your Needle!
Give me thy hand good Needle: thou camest timely.
Take off my hood and coat. And let me shake
Myself a little. I have a world of business.
Where is my Nephew Bias? and his wife?
Who bids God give them joy? Here they both stand
As sure affianced, as the Parson, or words
Can tie them.
We all wish them joy, and happiness.
I saw the Contract, and can witness it.
He shall receive ten thousand pounds tomorrow.
You looked for it, Compasse, or a greater sum;
But it is disposed of, this, another way.
I have but one Niece, verily Compasse.
I will find another.
Varlet, do your office.
I do arrest your body, Sir Moath Interest,
In the Kings name: At suite of Master. Compasse,
And Dame Placentia his wife. The Action is entered,
Five hundred thousand pound.
Hear you this, sister?
And hath your house the ears, to hear it too?
And to resound the affront?
I cannot stop
The Laws, or hinder Justice. I can be
Your Bail, if it may be taken.
With the Captains,
I ask no better.
Here are better men,
Will give their Bail.
But yours will not be taken,
Worshipful Doctor; you are good security
For a suit of clothes, to the Taylor, that dares trust you:
But not for such a sum, as is this Action.
Varlet, You know my mind.
You must to prison, Sir,
Unless you can find Bail the Creditor likes.
I would fain find it, if you would show me where.
It is a terrible Action; more indeed,
Than many a man is worth. And is called fright-bail.
Faith I will bail him, at mine own apperil.
Varlet, be gone: I will once have the reputation,
To be security for such a sum.
Bear up Sir Moath.
He is not worth the Buckles
About his Belt, and yet his Ironside clashes:
Peace, lest he hear you Doctor; we will make use of him.
What doth your brother Compasse, Captain Ironside,
Demand of us, by way of challenge, thus?
Your Niece's portion; in the right of his wife.
I have assured one portion, to one Niece,
And have no more to account for, that I know of:
What I may do in charity -- if my sister,
Will bid an Offering for her maid, and him,
As a Benevolence to them, after Supper,
I will spit into the Basin, and entreat
My friends to do the like.
Spit out thy gall,
And heart, thou Viper: I will now no mercy,
No pity of thee, thy false Niece, and Needle;
Bring forth your Child, or I appeal you of murder,
You, and this Gossip here, and Mother Chair.
The Gentleman is fallen mad!
No, Mistress. Midwife.
I saw the Child, and you did give it me,
And put it in my arms, by this ill token,
You wished me such another; and it cried.
The Law is plain; if it were heard to cry,
And you produce it not, he may indict
All that conceal it, of Felony, and Murder.
And I will take the boldness, Sir, to do it:
Beginning with Sir Moath here, and his Doctor.
Good faith this fame is like to turn a business.
And a shrewd business, marry: they all start at it.
I have the right thread now, and I will keep it.
You goody Keep, confess the truth to my Lady,
The truth, the whole truth, nothing but the truth.
I scorn to be prevented of my glories.
I plotted the deceit, and I will own it.
Love to my Child, and lucre of the portion
Provoked me; wherein though the event hath failed
In part, I will make use of the best side.
This is my Daughter, and she hath had a Child
This day, unto her shame, I now profess it.)
By this mere false-stick Squire Needle, but
Since this wise Knight, hath thought it good to change
The foolish Father of it, by assuring
her to his dear friend, Master. Bias; and him
Again to her, by clapping of him on
With his free promise of ten thousand pound,
Afore so many witnesses.
Whereof I
Am one.
And I another.
I should be unnatural
To my own flesh, and blood, would I not thank him.
I thank you Sir: and I have reason for it.
For here your true Niece stands, fine Mistress. Compasse.
(I will tell you truth, you have deserved it from me.)
To whom you are by bond engaged to pay
The sixteen thousand pound, which is her portion,
Due to her husband, on her marriage-day.
I speak the truth, and nothing but the truth.
You will pay it now, Sir Moath, with interest?
You see the truth breaks out on every side of you.
Into what nets of cozenage am I cast
On every side? each thread is grown a noose:
A very mesh: I have run myself into
A double-break, of paying twice the money.
You shall be released of paying me a penny,,
With these conditions.
Will you leave her then?
Yes, and the sum, twice told, ere take a wife,
To pick out Monsieur Needles basting threads.
Gossip you are paid: though he be a fit nature,
Worthy to have a Whore justly put on him;
He is not bad enough to take your Daughter,
On such a cheat. Will you yet pay the portion?
What will you bate?
No penny the Law gives.
Yes, Bias's money.
What? your friend in Court?
I will not rob you of him, nor the purchase,
Nor your dear Doctor here, stand altogether.
Birds of a nature all, and of a feather.
Well, we are all now reconciled to truth.
There rests yet a Gratuity from me,
To be conferred upon this Gentleman;
Who (as my Nephew Compasse says) was cause,
First of the offence, but since of all the amends,
The Quarrel caused the affright; that fright brought on
The travel, which made peace: the peace drew on
This new discovery, which endeth all
In reconcilement.
When the portion
Is tendered, and received.
Well, you must have it,
As good at first as last. It is well said brother.
And I, if this good Captain will accept me,
Give him myself, endow him with my estate,
And make him Lord of me, and all my fortunes:
He that hath saved my hour, though by chance,
I will really study his, and how to thank him.
And I embrace you, Lady, and your goodness,
And vow to quit all thought of war hereafter;
Save what is fought under your colours, Madam.
More work than for the Parson; I shall cap
The Loadstone with an Ironside, I see.
And take in these, the forlorn Couple, with us,
Needle, and his Thread, whose portion I will think on;
As being a business, waiting on my bounty:
Thus I do take possession of you, Madam,
My true Magnetic Mistress, and my Lady.
Well, Gentlemen, I now must under seal,
And the AUTHORS charge, waive you, and make my appeal
To the supremest power, my LORD, the KING;
Who best can judge of what we humbly bring.
He knows our weakness, and the Poet's faults;
Where he doth stand upright, go firm, or halts;
And he will doom him. To which voice he stands,
And prefers that, before all the Peoples hands.
